thread.title: Trinity unable to hold off OMA for second time this season
thread.title_full: Trinity unable to hold off OMA for second time this season

title: Trinity unable to hold off OMA for second time this season
text:
Trinity unable to hold off OMA for second time this season Friday, October 09, 2015 Comments 
Trinity Christian’s volleyball team can only hope the third meeting is a charm this season against Oak Mountain of Carrollton. 
The two programs, which played for last year’s GISA state championship, met for the second time in 2015 on Thursday, this one to decide this year’s Region 1-AAA title. 
Looking to avenge one of just three losses, the Lady Lions won the first set but couldn’t carry the momentum over en route to a 3-1 loss to the Lady Warriors. 
“It was a good match,” said Trinity head coach Joe Herrera. “We just made too many errors and you can’t do that against a team like them. We’ll move on from this and it’s likely that we’ll see them again down the road at state.” 
Trinity (28-4, 4-2) won the first set 25-23 before Oak Mountain (24-3, 10-0) responded for consecutive 25-12, 25-23 and 25-17 deci- sions to clinch this year’s region title. 
The Lady Lions have region matches left on Monday at Weber School and Thursday at home against Dominion Christian where the team will honor junior Cheyenne Hayes for posting the 1,000th kill of her career. 
Hayes added 14 more kills and seniors Katie Jones and Chasey Mitchell added six and four, respectively against Oak Moun- tain. Among Trinity’s 32 digs, Hayes had 10 while Jones and Senior Kelsey Richards added eight and six, respectively. 
Seniors Regan Lohlein, Libby Rogers and Mitchell each had a team-high two blocks and Lohlein finished with 28 assists from her setter position. More
